Telephone system.general assessment: Telecom Cook Islands offers international direct dialing, Internet, email, fax, and Telex
Telephone system.domestic: individual islands are connected by a combination of satellite earth stations, microwave systems, and VHF and HF radiotelephone; within the islands, service is provided by small exchanges connected to subscribers by open-wire, cable, and fiber-optic cable
Telephone system.international: country code - 682; satellite earth station - 1 Intelsat (Pacific Ocean)

Broadcast media.value: 1 privately owned TV station broadcasts from Rarotonga providing a mix of local news and overseas-sourced programs; a satellite program package is available; 6 radio stations broadcast with 1 reportedly reaching all of the islands (2009)

Industries.value: fruit processing, tourism, fishing, clothing, handicrafts

Agriculture - products.value: copra, citrus, pineapples, tomatoes, beans, pawpaws, bananas, yams, taro, coffee; pigs, poultry

Economy - overview.value: Like many other South Pacific island nations, the Cook Islands' economic development is hindered by the isolation of the country from foreign markets, the limited size of domestic markets, lack of natural resources, periodic devastation from natural disasters, and inadequate infrastructure. Agriculture, employing more than one-quarter of the working population, provides the economic base with major exports of copra and citrus fruit. Black pearls are the Cook Islands' leading export. Manufacturing activities are limited to fruit processing, clothing, and handicrafts. Trade deficits are offset by remittances from emigrants and by foreign aid overwhelmingly from New Zealand. In the 1980s and 1990s, the country lived beyond its means, maintaining a bloated public service and accumulating a large foreign debt. Subsequent reforms, including the sale of state assets, the strengthening of economic management, the encouragement of tourism, and a debt restructuring agreement, have rekindled investment and growth.

Imports - commodities.value: foodstuffs, textiles, fuels, timber, capital goods

Exports - commodities.value: copra, papayas, fresh and canned citrus fruit, coffee; fish; pearls and pearl shells; clothing

Environment - international agreements.party to: Biodiversity, Climate Change, Climate Change-Kyoto Protocol, Desertification, Hazardous Wastes, Law of the Sea, Ozone Layer Protection

Location.value: Oceania, group of islands in the South Pacific Ocean, about halfway between Hawaii and New Zealand

Geography - note.value: the northern Cook Islands are seven low-lying, sparsely populated, coral atolls; the southern Cook Islands, where most of the population lives, consist of eight elevated, fertile, volcanic isles, including the largest, Rarotonga, at 67 sq km

Terrain.value: low coral atolls in north; volcanic, hilly islands in south

Area - comparative.value: 1.3 times the size of Washington, DC

Climate.value: tropical oceanic; moderated by trade winds; a dry season from April to November and a more humid season from December to March

Land use.value: arable land 4.2%; permanent crops 4.2%; permanent pasture 0%

Maritime claims.continental shelf: 200 nm or to the edge of the continental margin

Merchant marine.by type: bulk carrier 2, cargo 25, passenger 1, refrigerated cargo 6, roll on/roll off 1
Merchant marine.foreign-owned: 23 (Estonia 1, Germany 1, Lithuania 1, Norway 8, NZ 2, Russia 1, Sweden 3, Turkey 4, UK 2) (2010)

Military branches.value: no regular military forces; National Police Department (2009)

Military - note.value: defense is the responsibility of New Zealand in consultation with the Cook Islands and at its request

Diplomatic representation in the US.value: none (self-governing in free association with New Zealand)

Political pressure groups and leaders.value: Reform Conference (lobby for political system changes)
Political pressure groups and leaders.other: various groups lobbying for political change

Dependency status.value: self-governing in free association with New Zealand; Cook Islands is fully responsible for internal affairs; New Zealand retains responsibility for external affairs and defense in consultation with the Cook Islands

Diplomatic representation from the US.value: none (self-governing in free association with New Zealand)

Legal system.value: common law similar to New Zealand common law

Legislative branch.description: unicameral Parliament, formerly the Legislative Assembly (24 seats; members directly elected in single-seat constituencies by simple majority vote to serve 4-year terms); note - the House of Ariki, a 24-member parliamentary body of traditional leaders appointed by the Queen's representative serves as a consultative body to the Parliament
Legislative branch.elections: last held on 9 July 2014 (next to be held by 2018)
Legislative branch.election results: percent of vote by party - NA; seats by party - CIP 13, Demo 8, One Cook Islands Movement 2, 1 undecided

Constitution.value: effective 4 August 1965 (Cook islands Constitution Act 1964); amended many times, last in 2004 (2004)

International law organization participa.value: has not submitted an ICJ jurisdiction declaration (New Zealand normally retains responsibility for external affairs); accepts ICCt jurisdiction

National anthem.name: "Te Atua Mou E" (To God Almighty)
National anthem.note: adopted 1982; as prime minister, Sir Thomas DAVIS composed the anthem; his wife, a tribal chief, wrote the lyrics

Executive branch.chief of state: Queen ELIZABETH II (since 6 February 1952); represented by Tom J. MARSTERS (since 9 August 2013); New Zealand High Commissioner Joanna KEMPKERS (since 19 July 2013)
Executive branch.cabinet: Cabinet chosen by the prime minister
Executive branch.elections/appointments: the monarchy is hereditary; UK representative appointed by the monarch; New Zealand high commissioner appointed by the New Zealand Government; following legislative elections, the leader of the majority party or majority coalition usually becomes prime minister

Independence.value: none (became self-governing in free association with New Zealand on 4 August 1965 and has the right at any time to move to full independence by unilateral action)

National holiday.value: Constitution Day, first Monday in August (1965)

Capital.name: Avarua
Capital.time difference: UTC-10 (5 hours behind Washington, DC, during Standard Time)

National symbol(s).value: a circle of 15, five-pointed, white stars on a blue field; national colors: blue, white

Flag description.value: blue with the flag of the UK in the upper hoist-side quadrant and a large circle of 15 white five-pointed stars (one for every island) centered in the outer half of the flag

Judicial branch.highest resident court(s): Court of Appeal (consists of the chief justice and 3 judges of the High Court); High Court (consists of the chief justice and at least 4 judges and organized into civil, criminal, and land divisions); note - appeals beyond the Cook Islands Court of Appeal are brought before the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council (in London)
Judicial branch.judge selection and term of office: High Court chief justice appointed by the Queen's Representative on the advice of the Executive Council tendered by the prime minister; other judges appointed by the Queen's Representative, on the advice of the Executive Council tendered by the chief justice, High Court chief justice, and the minister of justice; chief justice and judges appointed for 3-year renewable terms

International organization participation.value: ACP, ADB, AOSIS, FAO, ICAO, ICCt, ICRM, IFAD, IFRCS, IMO, IMSO, IOC, ITUC (NGOs), OPCW, PIF, Sparteca, SPC, UNESCO, UPU, WHO, WMO

Background.value: Named after Captain COOK, who sighted them in 1770, the islands became a British protectorate in 1888. By 1900, administrative control was transferred to New Zealand; in 1965, residents chose self-government in free association with New Zealand. The emigration of skilled workers to New Zealand, government deficits, and limited natural resources are of continuing concern.

Languages.note: shares sum to more than 100% because some respondents gave more than one answer on the census (2011 est.)

Religions.value: Protestant 62.8% (Cook Islands Christian Church 49.1%, Seventh Day Adventist 7.9%, Assemblies of God 3.7%, Apostolic Church 2.1%), Roman Catholic 17%, Mormon 4.4%, other 8%, none 5.6%, no response 2.2% (2011 est.)

Ethnic groups.value: Cook Island Maori (Polynesian) 81.3%, part Cook Island Maori 6.7%, other 11.9% (2011 est.)

Population.note: the Cook Islands' Ministry of Finance & Economic Management estimated the resident population to have been 13,700 in September 2013 (July 2015 est.)
